message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of allergic rhinitis, which can be managed with intranasal steroids. Amoxicillin is not necessary as there are no signs of a bacterial infection. Intranasal saline can provide temporary relief but does not address the underlying inflammation. Loratadine can provide symptomatic relief but does not address the underlying inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of allergic rhinitis, and intranasal steroids are effective in reducing inflammation and managing symptoms. Amoxicillin is used to treat bacterial infections, which is not indicated in this case. Intranasal saline can provide symptomatic relief, but may not be enough for long term management. Loratadine is an antihistamine, but intranasal steroids are more effective in managing symptoms of allergic rhinitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, which can be treated with intranasal steroid to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms. Intranasal saline can also be used to flush out allergens but may not be as effective in treating symptoms as intranasal steroid. Amoxicillin is not indicated as there is no evidence of a bacterial infection. Loratadine can be used to relieve symptoms but will not address the underlying inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and intranasal steroids are the first-line treatment for this condition. Amoxicillin is only indicated if there is bacterial sinusitis, and this patient does not have any signs or symptoms of bacterial infection. Intranasal saline and loratadine may provide some relief for the symptoms but are not the best next step for management.

Amoxicillin is used for bacterial infections, which is not indicated here. Intranasal saline may provide some relief, but intranasal steroids are more effective. Loratadine is an oral antihistamine, which may help with symptoms but intranasal steroids are still the first line treatment.

We refer to medical literature on the management of persistent rhinitis. Based on the patient's symptoms and lack of any significant findings on physical examination, the most likely diagnosis is allergic rhinitis. Intranasal steroids are the recommended first-line treatment for persistent allergic rhinitis. Amoxicillin is not indicated as there is no evidence of bacterial infection. Intranasal saline may provide some relief, but is not a definitive treatment. Loratadine may provide symptomatic relief but does not address the underlying inflammation. Therefore, (C) intranasal steroid is the best next step in management.

Antibiotics are not indicated as there is no evidence of bacterial infection. Intranasal saline can provide symptom relief but may not adequately treat the underlying condition. Loratadine can be effective for allergic rhinitis, but intranasal steroids are typically preferred as a first-line treatment.
